Selected Answer: C
C is correct:

Under the same interfaces, another ip helper-address command is configured to point to the ISE PSN interface enabled with the DHCP probe. The ISE Policy Service node will not reply to these packets, but the goal is simply to send a copy of the requests to ISE for parsing of DHCP attributes. It is possible to configure multiple IP Helper targets on Cisco devices to allow multiple ISE Policy Service nodes to receive copies of the DHCP requests.

https://community.cisco.com/t5/security-knowledge-base/ise-profiling-design-guide/ta-p/3739456#toc-hId-826550277

Selected Answer: A
I am not really sure but after research I would say that :

--- Answer-A is more prone to be the correct one for the following reasons:
- Option 82 adds additional metadata (e.g., switch ID, port number, VLAN) into DHCP requests. Additionally it is an attribute as requested by the question.
- This metadata enhances ISE profiling more than just forwarding DHCP requests via relay.
- Without Option 82, ISE can still receive DHCP requests, but it lacks additional switch-related attributes.

--- Answer-B do not involve Cisco ISE profiles. MAC-to-IP mappings are typically used in DHCP Snooping and IP Source Guard.

--- Answer-C seems to be wrong as:
- Without Option 82, ISE can still receive DHCP requests, but it lacks additional switch-related attributes.

--- Answer-D has nothing to do with ISE profiling. DHCP snooping helps prevent rogue DHCP servers, but it does not add attributes to Cisco ISE profiles.

Selected Answer: A
Answer A is the correct one for the following reasons:

Answer-B do not involve Cisco ISE profiles. MAC-to-IP mappings are typically used in DHCP Snooping and IP Source Guard.

Answer-C seems to be wrong as mentioned in Cisco community forums:
1) https://community.cisco.com/t5/network-access-control/ise-with-dhcp-server/td-p/3540467
2) https://community.cisco.com/t5/network-access-control/can-we-use-ise-as-dhcp-dns-server-to-prevent-guest-traffic-using/m-p/4036321#M558382

Answer-D has nothing to do with ISE profiling. DHCP snooping helps prevent rogue DHCP servers, but it does not add attributes to Cisco ISE profiles.

https://www.cisco.com/c/es_mx/support/docs/wireless/4400-series-wireless-lan-controllers/113302-dhcp-option82-00.html

Selected Answer: D
Answer D. 

The task was to implement DHCP security (#1) and the ability to add additional attributes to profiles that are created within ISE (#2).

Additional attributes (#2) could be added with answer A (DHCP option 82).
DHCP security (#1) is implemented with answer D. Enabling DHCP snooping also enabling DHCP option 82. So both tasks are fullfiled with this.

Answer C makes no sense because of "Modify". Furthermore, this answer fails to achieve both goals.

It seems so, that the 2nd ip-helper address for ISE is already configured.

https://community.cisco.com/t5/switching/why-does-dhcp-snooping-insert-option-82-at-all/td-p/3091608

Selected Answer: C
DHCP profiling probe in ISE can be used if the ip-helper is set to ISE address (i. e. a copy of each DHCPDISCOVER packet is sent to ISE)
C. Modify the DHCP relay and point the IP address to Cisco ISE.

I will go for C!

D will not add additional attributes to ISE profiling.

questions.question_text: An engineer is implementing DHCP security mechanisms and needs the ability to add additional attributes to profiles that are created within Cisco ISE. Which action accomplishes this task?

choices.B: Define MAC-to-IP address mappings in the switch to ensure that rogue devices cannot get an IP address.
choices.A: Use DHCP option 82 to ensure that the request is from a legitimate endpoint and send the information to Cisco ISE.
choices.C: Modify the DHCP relay and point the IP address to Cisco ISE.
choices.D: Configure DHCP snooping on the switch VLANs and trust the necessary interfaces.

choices.C: P1, P2, P3, and P4 only

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
only the ports connected to actual workstations/clients are untrusted

Selected Answer: B
ums008 gave a good explanation. Typically all access ports, where the endpoints reside, are untrusted. We do not want to see DHCP offer from a rogue client. On the other hand, we want to allow DHCP offer from the legitimate DHCP server. As it is about the offer, it would be enough to trust the ports where the offer arrives. In case of uncertainty, we can trust all trunk ports with DHCP traffic, and the port where the DHCP server is sitting.

Typical Cisco SHIT question, you enable them on SVI as best practice. but if we decode this then it means all access ports in that vlan where we dont want to see a dhcp server. 

So B is the correct answer.

Selected Answer: D
SW1 and SW3 do not have DAI configured. Configure P5 and P7 is not possible.

comments.content:
This is not a typical DAI network as DAI is not enabled on all access ports with hosts (means SW1 and SW3 ). Therefore , you need to activate DAI on Trunk ports (fully supported , and you need to increase the DAI inspection limit to avoid bottlenecks).
So its D correct, not B.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is correct:

In a typical network configuration for DAI, all ports connected to host ports are configured as untrusted, while all ports connected to switches are configured as trusted. With this configuration, all ARP packets entering the network from a given switch will have passed the security check.

Configuring interfaces as untrusted when they should be trusted can result in a loss of connectivity. Configuring interfaces to be trusted when they are actually untrusted leaves a security hole in the network.

Reference: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/lan/catalyst4500/12-2/25ew/configuration/guide/conf/dynarp.html

Selected Answer: D
D - is correct:
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/lan/catalyst4500/12-2/25ew/configuration/guide/conf/dynarp.html#:~:text=Dynamic%20ARP%20Inspection%20%28DAI%29%20is%20a%20security%20feature,capability%20protects%20the%20network%20from%20certain%20%E2%80%9Cman-in-the-middle%E2%80%9D%20attacks.

To handle cases in which some switches in a VLAN run DAI and other switches do not, the interfaces connecting such switches should be configured as untrusted. To validate the bindings of packets from non-DAI switches, however, the switch running DAI should be configured with ARP ACLs. When it is not feasible to determine such bindings, switches running DAI should be isolated from non-DAI switches at Layer 3.

This question confused me, because how is the SW2 switch going to use the DHCP Snooping database from R1, to do DAI? The snooping database has to be local to the switch. But if you don't think about that part and only focus on SW2 and DAI. Ports 2,3 and 6 would have to be untrusted.
But wouldn't that also hinder traffic from the other switches?

questions.question_text: Which entity is responsible for encrypting data in transit using an IaaS model versus a SaaS model?

discussion.content:
The answer is D

In an IaaS (Infrastructure as a Service) model, the customer is responsible for encrypting data in transit. This is because the customer has control over the underlying infrastructure, including the servers, storage, and networking components. The customer can choose to use a variety of encryption methods, such as TLS/SSL, IPsec, or VPN.
In a SaaS (Software as a Service) model, the cloud provider is responsible for encrypting data in transit. This is because the cloud provider has control over the underlying infrastructure and the software application. The cloud provider will typically use TLS/SSL to encrypt data in transit.
https://bard.google.com/chat/73d702485234cc30

Selected Answer: D
The correct answer is: D. Cloud Service Customer for IaaS and Cloud Service Provider for SaaS

Selected Answer: C
c946f3e is right
